Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Couple thoughts/questions.

I think the following line was supposed to prevent this but it apparently does not:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v1/images.py#L791

I'm curious about why it doesn't. Also, could we perform this check in the api layer instead of the db layer? I wonder if this bug is present in glance v2 as well.

Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think maybe there are something wrong with the glance client, since bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-glanceclient/+bug/1240462 is also talking similar issue. So it would be nice to clarify why the code in line 790-791 can't catch this issue, as ameade mentioned above. Thanks.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3:

Alex, the case I am tying to cover here is where a request has gone beyond that check and then another request comes in. If we check the status during the locked sqlalchemy session then we know we can rely on it. I pointed out that we would ultimately need to have a proper taskflow here but this is just an interim safeguard. Take a look at the unit test to see that case i am trying to cover.

Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think I understand the case your test is trying to cover. When an image is in saving status, another request to update the image with image data should fail with an HTTP 409.

If I revert all of these changes except for the new test, it still passes. However, if I remove this line: https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v1/images.py#L791 it then fails.

I'm not sure if there is another issue here or not. I think what Fei was alluding to is that if someone issues two image-update requests with glance client, both with data, then they will both succeed. This is because glanceclient will grab the image before it issues the request and only actually send the data if the image is in queued state.

What was it that caused you to notice the issue? Could you elaborate? Sorry, not trying to drag this out. If anything we need this test to cover this case.

P.S. We are moving away from using mox (not py3 compat) and using mock instead

Thanks!

Patch Set 3:

According to the checking at [1] (and [2] if you using glanceclient trigger image-update request), I consider this issue is happen on race condition context only. So dosaboy's change is make sense to me to add a checking for image status during the locked sqlalchemy session (adding to api controller is useless since we have no distributed lock mechanism).

In future we can add a upload taskflow which contains necessary reversion for the status transfer task to make sure image's status can be restored to 'queue' from 'saving' if glance-api service dies during the uploading flow execution.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v1/images.py#L791
[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/v1/shell.py#L298

Thanks for the commit dosaboy. Could you please do unit test better as Alex Meade mentioned.

BTW, I'm also thinking, under current glance design, can we add a checking when glance-api daemon restart, and do the necessary image status status reversion such as change 'saving' back to 'queue'?
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm concerned about this getting images stuck in the 'saving' state if glance dies.

I think I have an alternate suggestion using WHERE clauses on the update from 'saving' to 'active'. Can we regroup around that idea when we get a chance?

Patch Set 8: No score

removing my -1 until I can make more sense!

Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I really do not like doing state transition enforcement in the DB layer.  I understand that this is an interim solution, however these things have a way of living on.

It seems that this points at a greater issue in glance.  We do not have a good way to manage states.  In this case it appears that we are trying to disallow the image state transition from saving -> saving.  Is it possible to find an interim solution that enforces this in a more appropriate place in the code?

Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(I think my sentiment at least partially agrees with John's. In any case I'm just trying to clarify my idea from earlier on this review.)

I think the right solution for this right now is to make the action to set the image status from 'SAVING' to 'ACTIVE' exclusive and atomic. In straight SQL this would look something like

'UPDATE images SET status = "active" WHERE id="blah" AND status = "saving"'

If no rows are affected, then you know something went wrong. When it goes wrong, we should remove added location, if any, and delete what was put up on the store. Basically, the loser in an update race recognizes that he has lost (relying on atomicity in the DB) and cleans up the mess.

Sound sensible? This will probably entail a minor change to the db api for image_update I guess.

Patch Set 8:

markwash: While I like your solution a bit better, that still sounds like the DB would be doing the enforcement.  If this issue is critical enough in the short term to require such a kludge then perhaps that is what needs to be done, but it would probably be best if that was clear.

Further, I am hoping that no data will actually be uploaded before this failure occurs.  I think that is case, but perhaps we should verify that as well.

Patch Set 8: No score

Seems we'd like to make a final solution/thoughts based on this bug/patch. I like to know other folks's more comments.

btw, actually I still think dosboy just try to do an interim solution to quick fix this defect for glance. Anyway, more thinking will be better always.

Patch Set 8:

Ok, so I've done a bit more testing on this.

Firstly to be clear, the issue this patch aims to resolve is where concurrent
requests for the same image hit the api and are processed such that more than
one request manages to transition the image from 'queued' to 'saving'. This is
obviously a very small window - the time between the api checking the status
and the regsitry processing the state change - and as such is hard to hit.
Using scenario tests that triggering multiple concurrent update requests to
upload data to an already 'queued' image, I was not able to reproduce the
error. Having said that, the unit test provided as part of this patchset
hopefully highlights the case where the error can theoretically occur.

Now, as it stands this patch can have the side effect of images getting stuck
if upload does not complete and the image remains in 'saving' state. A common
and easily reproducible example of this is if the glance api restarts mid
update/upload. Thing is, this behaviour currently exists anyway if the api gets
restarted wile the image is in 'saving' state, so applying this new patch would
close another gap while not actually creating any new side effects.

If we still don't want to go down this route then I can't see any other way to
achieve this protection without a much larger code change which, as previously
pointed out, would likely involve modifications to the db api since the only
unit of atomitcity across nodes that we currently have in Glance (afaik) is the
db session. I may well be wrong though and welcome comments/suggestions. (I am,
by the way, ignoring any potential taskflow work since this was only ever
intended as an interim solution.)
